title: 114_s303
content: The Act titled "Federal Employee Tax Accountability Act of 2015" prohibits individuals with seriously delinquent tax debts from federal employment. This amendment adds limitations on bonuses in Chapter 45 of title 5, United States Code. The "Federal Employee Tax Accountability Act of 2015" prohibits individuals with seriously delinquent tax debts from federal employment. This amendment adds restrictions on bonuses in Chapter 45 of title 5, United States Code, defining terms like agency, bonus, employee, and seriously delinquent tax debt. The term 'seriously delinquent tax debt' refers to an outstanding debt under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 with a notice of lien filed in public records. It excludes debts being paid timely under agreements, debts with pending collection due process hearings, and debts subject to relief under specific sections of the Code. Sec. 4532. Ineligibility for bonuses due to seriously delinquent tax debt under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Individuals with such debts are ineligible to receive bonuses from an agency. Applicants for employment must agree to be subject to levies issued under specific sections of the Code. Individuals seeking employment with a federal agency must certify that they do not have seriously delinquent tax debt. The Office of Personnel Management will establish regulations in consultation with the IRS, ensuring due process rights for individuals deemed ineligible for bonuses due to tax debt. Individuals have 180 days to prove their debt falls under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code. The Office of Personnel Management will report annually to Congress on exemptions made for employees with seriously delinquent tax debt. Agencies must review public records to check for tax liens on employees or applicants. The agency can request an employee or applicant to authorize disclosure of tax debt information and contact the Secretary of the Treasury for tax details. The Secretary of the Treasury will provide a standard authorization form for this purpose. The agency must not negatively consider an individual based on tax debt when considering employment. In evaluating an individual for employment or performance appraisal, negative consideration should not be given for refusal to comply with information requests. Confidentiality rules prohibit the use of provided information for any purpose other than administration and prevent disclosure to unauthorized individuals. The Act includes limitations on bonuses, definitions, ineligibility criteria, review of public records, and confidentiality rules. The Act and its amendments will take effect nine months after enactment.
